summary: This document appears to be a transcript or summary of a speaker series or internal discussion where investigators involved in the Jeffrey Epstein death investigation at MCC New York describe the challenges they faced. The speakers detail the complexity of the case, the high-profile nature, issues with information flow, witness interviews, and the massive volume of documentation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'JE' and 'Epstein'. The investigation centers on the circumstances surrounding his death while in custody at MCC New York.

events.title: Epstein's Death and Initial Investigation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, prompting a high-profile investigation by the FBI and OIG.

events.title: OIG Investigation into Custody and Death
events.description: The Office of the Inspector General (OIG) conducted a detailed investigation (referred to as the '016 investigation') into the custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at MCC New York, involving re-interviews of witnesses and review of massive documentation.

locations: MCC New York (Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York)
SHU (Special Housing Unit, likely at MCC)
keyFacts: The investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death was described as extremely complex, with high public and press interest causing major challenges from the start.

Information flow was a significant problem; simultaneous interviews by different agents/AUSAs meant interviewers often lacked the most current information, leading to witnesses being interviewed multiple times.
Investigators conducted numerous re-interviews in 2021-2022, finding that witnesses often disputed their prior statements from 2019, requiring clarification and follow-up on missed topics.
Investigators faced obstructive behavior from some witnesses and their union representatives, and had to deal with conspiracy theories from Epstein's family members.
A critical method was using documentary evidence (count slips, round sheets, emails) during interviews to identify inaccuracies, false entries, and employee job failures.
